pages.title: Snub pentapentagonal tiling
Snub tetraapeirogonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|Ui4_s}}
In [[geometry]], the '''snub tetraapeirogonal tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of sr{∞,4}.

== Images ==
Drawn in chiral pairs, with edges missing between black triangles:
:[[File:H2 snub 24ia.png|240px]][[File:H2 snub 24ib.png|240px]]

== Related polyhedra and tiling ==
The ''snub tetrapeirogonal tiling '' is last in an infinite series of snub polyhedra and tilings with [[vertex figure]] 3.3.4.3.''n''.
{{Snub4 table}}

{{Order i-4 tiling table}}

pages.title: Snub triapeirogonal tiling
Snub triapeirotrigonal tiling
Snub triheptagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U73_s}}
In [[geometry]], the '''order-3 snub heptagonal tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the hyperbolic plane. There are four [[triangle]]s, one [[heptagon]] on each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of ''sr{7,3}''.  The [[snub tetraheptagonal tiling]] is another related hyperbolic tiling with Schläfli symbol ''sr{7,4}''.

== Images ==
Drawn in chiral pairs, with edges missing between black triangles:
:[[File:H2 snub 237a.png|240px]][[File:H2 snub 237b.png|240px]]

== Dual tiling ==

The dual tiling is called an ''order-7-3 floret pentagonal tiling'', and is related to the [[floret pentagonal tiling]].
:[[Image:Ord7 3 floret penta til.png|250px]]

== Related polyhedra and tilings ==
This semiregular tiling is a member of a sequence of [[Snub (geometry)|snubbed]] polyhedra and tilings with vertex figure (3.3.3.3.''n'') and [[Coxeter–Dynkin diagram]] {{CDD|node_h|n|node_h|3|node_h}}. These figures and their duals have (n32) rotational [[Orbifold notation|symmetry]], being in the Euclidean plane for n=6, and hyperbolic plane for any higher n. The series can be considered to begin with n=2, with one set of faces degenerated into [[digon]]s.
{{Snub table}}

From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are eight hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular heptagonal tiling. 

Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 8 forms.
{{Heptagonal tiling table}}

==References==
* [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{isbn|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations)
* {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}}

== See also ==
{{Commonscat|Uniform tiling 3-3-3-3-7}}

pages.title: Snub trioctagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U83_s}}
In [[geometry]], the '''order-3 snub octagonal tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the hyperbolic plane. There are four [[triangle]]s, one [[octagon]] on each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of ''sr{8,3}''.

== Images ==
Drawn in chiral pairs, with edges missing between black triangles:
:[[File:H2 snub 238a.png|240px]][[File:H2 snub 238b.png|240px]]

== Related polyhedra and tilings ==
This semiregular tiling is a member of a sequence of [[Snub (geometry)|snubbed]] polyhedra and tilings with vertex figure (3.3.3.3.''n'') and [[Coxeter–Dynkin diagram]] {{CDD|node_h|n|node_h|3|node_h}}. These figures and their duals have (n32) rotational [[Orbifold notation|symmetry]], being in the Euclidean plane for n=6, and hyperbolic plane for any higher n. The series can be considered to begin with n=2, with one set of faces degenerated into [[digon]]s.
{{Snub table}}

From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are ten hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular octagonal tiling. 

Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 10 forms.
{{Octagonal tiling table}}

==References==
* [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{isbn|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations)

pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U73_1}} In [[geometry]], the '''triheptagonal tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the hyperbolic plane, representing a [[Rectification (geometry)|rectified]] [[Order-3 heptagonal tiling]]. There are two [[triangle]]s and two [[heptagon]]s alternating on each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of r{7,3}. Compare to [[trihexagonal tiling]] with [[vertex configuration]] ''3.6.3.6''. == Images == {| class=wikitable width=480 |- valign=top |[[File:Uniform tiling 73-t1 klein.png|240px]]
[[Klein disk model]] of this tiling preserves straight lines, but distorts angles |[[Image:Order73_qreg_rhombic_til.png|240px]]
The dual tiling is called an ''Order-7-3 rhombille tiling'', made from rhombic faces, alternating 3 and 7 per vertex. |} == 7-3 Rhombille == {{Infobox face-uniform tiling | Name=7-3 rhombille tiling | Image_File=Image:Order73_qreg_rhombic_til.png | Type= | Cox={{CDD|node|3|node_f1|7|node}} | Face_List=Rhombi | Symmetry_Group=[7,3], *732 | Rotation_Group= [7,3]+, (732) | Face_Type=V3.7.3.7 | Dual=[[Triheptagonal tiling]] | Property_List=[[edge-transitive]] [[face-transitive]] }} In [[geometry]], the '''7-3 rhombille tiling''' is a [[tessellation]] of identical [[rhombus|rhombi]] on the [[hyperbolic plane]]. Sets of three and seven rhombi meet two classes of vertices. [[File:Order 7-3 rhombic tiling in the Band Model.png|640px]]
7-3 rhombile tiling in band model {{-}} == Related polyhedra and tilings == The triheptagonal tiling can be seen in a sequence of [[quasiregular polyhedron]]s and tilings: {{Quasiregular3 table}} From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are eight hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular heptagonal tiling. Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 8 forms. {{Heptagonal tiling table}} {{Quasiregular7 table}} == See also == {{Commonscat|Uniform tiling 3-7-3-7}} * [[Trihexagonal tiling]] - 3.6.3.6 tiling ** [[Rhombille tiling]] - dual V3.6.3.6 tiling * [[Tilings of regular polygons]] * [[List of uniform tilings]] ==References== * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{isbn|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.plunk.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Isotoxal tilings]] [[Category:Quasiregular polyhedra]] [[Category:Semiregular tilings]] {{geometry-stub}}

pages.title: Trioctagonal tiling
Truncated heptagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U73_01}}
In [[geometry]], the '''truncated heptagonal tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the hyperbolic plane. There are one [[triangle]] and two [[tetradecagon]]s on each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of ''t''{7,3}. The tiling has a [[vertex configuration]] of 3.14.14.

== Dual tiling ==
     
The dual tiling is called an ''order-7 triakis triangular tiling'', seen as an [[order-7 triangular tiling]] with each triangle divided into three by a center point.
:[[Image:Ord7 triakis triang til.png|250px]]

== Related polyhedra and tilings ==
This hyperbolic tiling is topologically related as a part of sequence of uniform [[Truncation (geometry)|truncated]] polyhedra with [[vertex configuration]]s (3.2n.2n), and [n,3] [[Coxeter group]] symmetry.
{{Truncated figure1 table}}

From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are eight hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular heptagonal tiling. 

Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are eight forms.
{{Heptagonal tiling table}}

pages.title: Truncated hexaoctagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U86_012}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated hexaoctagonal tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the hyperbolic plane. There are one [[Square (geometry)|square]], one [[dodecagon]], and one [[hexakaidecagon]] on each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of tr{8,6}. == Dual tiling== {| class=wikitable width=480 |[[File:Hyperbolic domains 862.png|160px]] |[[File:H2checkers_268.png|160px]] |- |colspan=2|The dual tiling is called an ''order-6-8 kisrhombille tiling'', made as a complete bisection of the [[order-6 octagonal tiling]], here with triangles are shown with alternating colors. This tiling represents the fundamental triangular domains of [8,6] (*862) symmetry. |} == Symmetry== [[File:H2_tiling_268-7-mirrors.png|thumb|left| Truncated hexaoctagonal tiling with mirror lines]] There are six reflective subgroup kaleidoscopic constructed from [8,6] by removing one or two of three mirrors. Mirrors can be removed if its branch orders are all even, and cuts neighboring branch orders in half. Removing two mirrors leaves a half-order gyration point where the removed mirrors met. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and white, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. The [[subgroup index]]-8 group, [1+,8,1+,6,1+] (4343) is the [[commutator subgroup]] of [8,6]. A radical subgroup is constructed as [8,6*], index 12, as [8,6+], (6*4) with gyration points removed, becomes (*444444), and another [8*,6], index 16 as [8+,6], (8*3) with gyration points removed as (*33333333). {| class=wikitable |+ Small index subgroups of [8,6] (*862) |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !colspan=3|2 !colspan=2|4 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:862 symmetry mirrors.png|120px]] |[[File:862 symmetry 00a.png|120px]] |[[File:862 symmetry a00.png|120px]] |[[File:862 symmetry 0a0.png|120px]] |[[File:862 symmetry z0z.png|120px]] |[[File:862 symmetry xxx.png|120px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]] |[8,6]
{{CDD|node_c2|8|node_c3|6|node_c1}} = {{CDD|node_c3|split1-86|branch_c2-1}} |[1+,8,6]
{{CDD|node_h0|8|node_c3|6|node_c1}} = {{CDD|label4|branch_c3|split2-66|node_c1}} |[8,6,1+]
{{CDD|node_c2|8|node_c3|6|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node_c2|split1-88|branch_c3}} = {{CDD|node_c2|split1-88|branch_c3}} |[8,1+,6]
{{CDD|node_c2|8|node_h0|6|node_c1}} = {{CDD|label4|branch_c2|2a2b-cross|branch_c1}} |[1+,8,6,1+]
{{CDD|node_h0|8|node_c3|6|node_h0}} = {{CDD|label4|branch_c3|3a3b-cross|branch_c3|label4}} |[8+,6+]

pages.title: Truncated infinite-order square tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|Ui4_12}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated infinite-order square tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of t{4,∞}. == Uniform color== In (*∞44) symmetry this tiling has 3 colors. Bisecting the isosceles triangle domains can double the symmetry to [[i42 symmetry|*∞42 symmetry]]. :[[File:H2checkers 44i.png|200px]][[File:H2 tiling 44i-7.png|200px]] === Symmetry === The dual of the tiling represents the fundamental domains of (*∞44) [[Orbifold notation|orbifold]] symmetry. From [(∞,4,4)] (*∞44) symmetry, there are 15 small index subgroup (11 unique) by mirror removal and alternation operators. Mirrors can be removed if its branch orders are all even, and cuts neighboring branch orders in half. Removing two mirrors leaves a half-order gyration point where the removed mirrors met. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and white, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. The symmetry can be doubled to [[i42 symmetry|*∞42]] by adding a bisecting mirror across the fundamental domains. The [[subgroup index]]-8 group, [(1+,∞,1+,4,1+,4)] (∞22∞22) is the [[commutator subgroup]] of [(∞,4,4)]. {| class=wikitable |+ Small index subgroups of [(∞,4,4)] (*∞44) |- align=center !Fundamental
domains ![[File:H2checkers 44i.png|120px]] !|[[File:H2chess 44ie.png|80px]]

pages.title: Truncated infinite-order triangular tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|Ui3_12}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated infinite-order triangular tiling''' is a [[uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tiling]] of the [[hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]] with a [[Schläfli symbol]] of t{3,∞}. == Symmetry== [[File:Truncated_infinite-order_triangular_tiling_with_mirrors.png|left|thumb|Truncated infinite-order triangular tiling with mirror lines, {{CDD|node_c1|split1|branch_c1|labelinfin}}.]] The dual of this tiling represents the fundamental domains of *∞33 symmetry. There are no mirror removal subgroups of [(∞,3,3)], but this symmetry group can be doubled to [[i32 symmetry|∞32 symmetry]] by adding a mirror. {| class=wikitable |+ Small index subgroups of [(∞,3,3)], (*∞33) |- align=center !Type !Reflectional !Rotational |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !2 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:i33_symmetry_000.png|160px]] |[[File:i33_symmetry_aaa.png|160px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]]
([[Orbifold notation|orbifold]]) |[(∞,3,3)]
{{CDD|node_c1|split1|branch_c1|labelinfin}}
(*∞33) |[(∞,3,3)]+
{{CDD|node_h2|split1|branch_h2h2|labelinfin}}
(∞33) |} == Related polyhedra and tiling == This hyperbolic tiling is topologically related as a part of sequence of uniform [[truncation (geometry)|truncated]] polyhedra with [[vertex configuration]]s (6.n.n), and [n,3] [[Coxeter group]] symmetry. {{Truncated figure2 table}} {{Order i-3 tiling table}} {{Order_i-3-3_tiling_table}} ==See also== {{Commons category|Uniform tiling 6-6-i}} *[[List of uniform planar tilings]] *[[Tilings of regular polygons]] *[[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{refbegin}} * [[John Horton Conway|John H. pages.title: Truncated octagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U83_01}}
In [[geometry]], the '''Truncated octagonal tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the hyperbolic plane. There is one [[triangle]] and two [[hexakaidecagon]]s on each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of ''t''{8,3}.

== Dual tiling==
The dual tiling has face configuration V3.16.16.
:[[File:Ord8 triakis triang til.png|240px]]

== Related polyhedra and tilings ==
This hyperbolic tiling is topologically related as a part of sequence of uniform [[Truncation (geometry)|truncated]] polyhedra with [[vertex configuration]]s (3.2n.2n), and [n,3] [[Coxeter group]] symmetry.
{{Truncated figure1 table}}

From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are ten hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular octagonal tiling. 

Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 8 forms.
{{Octagonal tiling table}}

== See also ==
{{Commonscat|Uniform tiling 3-16-16}}
* [[Truncated hexagonal tiling]]
* [[Octagonal tiling]]
* [[Tilings of regular polygons]]
* [[List of uniform tilings]]

==References==
* [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{isbn|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations)
* {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}}

pages.title: Truncated order-3 apeirogonal tiling
Truncated order-4 apeirogonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|Ui4_01}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated order-4 apeirogonal tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of t{∞,4}. == Uniform colorings == A half symmetry coloring is tr{∞,∞}, has two types of apeirogons, shown red and yellow here. If the apeirogonal curvature is too large, it doesn't converge to a single ideal point, like the right image, red apeirogons below. [[Coxeter diagram]] are shown with dotted lines for these divergent, [[ultraparallel]] mirrors. {| class=wikitable |- align=center |[[File:H2 tiling 2ii-7.png|200px]]
{{CDD|node_1|infin|node_1|infin|node_1}}
(Vertex centered) |[[File:H2 tiling 2iu-7.png|200px]]
{{CDD|node_1|infin|node_1|ultra|node_1}}
(Square centered) |} == Symmetry== From [∞,∞] symmetry, there are 15 small index subgroup by mirror removal and alternation. Mirrors can be removed if its branch orders are all even, and cuts neighboring branch orders in half. Removing two mirrors leaves a half-order gyration point where the removed mirrors met. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and white, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. pages.title: Truncated order-4 heptagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U74_01}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated order-4 heptagonal tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of t{7,4}. == Constructions == There are two uniform constructions of this tiling, first by the [7,4] [[kaleidoscope]], and second by removing the last mirror, [7,4,1+], gives [7,7], (*772). {| class=wikitable |+ Two uniform constructions of 4.7.4.7 |- align=center !Name !Tetraheptagonal !Truncated heptahexagonal |- align=center !Image |[[File:Uniform tiling 74-t01.png|100px]] |[[File:Uniform_tiling_77-t012.png|100px]] |- align=center ![[Hyperbolic symmetry|Symmetry]] |[7,4]
(*742)
{{CDD|node_c1|7|node_c2|4|node_c3}} |[7,7] = [7,4,1+]
(*772)
{{CDD|node_c1|split1-77|nodeab_c2}} = {{CDD|node_c1|7|node_c2|4|node_h0}} |- align=center !Symbol |t{7,4} |tr{7,7} |- align=center ![[Coxeter diagram]] |{{CDD|node_1|7|node_1|4|node}} |{{CDD|node_1|7|node_1|7|node_1}} |} == Symmetry == There is only one simple subgroup [7,7]+, index 2, removing all the mirrors. This symmetry can be doubled to [[742 symmetry]] by adding a bisecting mirror. {| class=wikitable |+ Small index subgroups of [7,7] |- align=center !Type !Reflectional !Rotational |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !2 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:772_symmetry_000.png|160px]] |[[File:772_symmetry_aaa.png|160px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]]
([[Orbifold notation|orbifold]]) |[7,7] = {{CDD|node_c1|7|node_c1|7|node_c1}}
(*772) |[7,7]+ = {{CDD|node_h2|7|node_h2|7|node_h2}}
(772) |} == Related polyhedra and tiling == {{Truncated_figure3_table}} {{Order 7-4 tiling table}} {{Order 7-7 tiling table}} ==References== * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{isbn|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} ==See also== {{Commonscat|Uniform tiling 4-14-14}} *[[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane]] *[[List of regular polytopes]] == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.plunk.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Heptagonal tilings]] [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Order-4 tilings]] [[Category:Truncated tilings]] [[Category:Uniform tilings]] {{geometry-stub}}

pages.title: Truncated order-4 hexagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U64_01}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated order-4 hexagonal tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of t{6,4}. A secondary construction tr{6,6} is called a '''truncated hexahexagonal tiling''' with two colors of [[dodecagon]]s. == Constructions == There are two uniform constructions of this tiling, first from [6,4] [[kaleidoscope]], and a lower symmetry by removing the last mirror, [6,4,1+], gives [6,6], (*662). {| class=wikitable |+ Two uniform constructions of 4.6.4.6 |- align=center !Name !Tetrahexagonal !Truncated hexahexagonal |- align=center !Image |[[File:Uniform tiling 64-t01.png|100px]] |[[File:Uniform_tiling_66-t012.png|100px]] |- align=center ![[Hyperbolic symmetry|Symmetry]] |[6,4]
(*642)
{{CDD|node_c1|6|node_c2|4|node_c3}} |[6,6] = [6,4,1+]
(*662)
{{CDD|node_c1|split1-66|nodeab_c2}} = {{CDD|node_c1|6|node_c2|4|node_h0}} |- align=center !Symbol |t{6,4} |tr{6,6} |- align=center ![[Coxeter diagram]] |{{CDD|node_1|6|node_1|4|node}} |{{CDD|node_1|6|node_1|6|node_1}} |} == Dual tiling == {| class=wikitable width=320 |- |[[File:Order-6_tetrakis_square_tiling.png|160px]] |[[File:Hyperbolic domains 662.png|160px]] |- |colspan=2|The dual tiling, ''order-6 tetrakis square tiling'' has [[face configuration]] V4.12.12, and represents the fundamental domains of the [6,6] symmetry group. |} == Related polyhedra and tiling == {{Truncated figure3 table}} {{Order 6-4 tiling table}} {{Order 6-6 tiling table}} === Symmetry=== [[File:Truncated_order-4_hexagonal_tiling_with_mirrors.png|left|thumb|Truncated order-4 hexagonal tiling with *662 mirror lines]] The dual of the tiling represents the fundamental domains of (*662) [[Orbifold notation|orbifold]] symmetry. From [6,6] (*662) symmetry, there are 15 small index subgroup (12 unique) by mirror removal and [[alternation (geometry)|alternation]] operators. Mirrors can be removed if its branch orders are all even, and cuts neighboring branch orders in half. Removing two mirrors leaves a half-order gyration point where the removed mirrors met. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and white, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. The [[subgroup index]]-8 group, [1+,6,1+,6,1+] (3333) is the [[commutator subgroup]] of [6,6]. Larger subgroup constructed as [6,6*], removing the gyration points of (6*3), index 12 becomes (*333333). The symmetry can be doubled to [[642 symmetry]] by adding a mirror to bisect the fundamental domain. {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" !colspan=12| Small index subgroups of [6,6] (*662) |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !colspan=3|2 !colspan=2|4 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:662_symmetry_000.png|120px]] |[[File:662_symmetry_a00.png|120px]] |[[File:662_symmetry_00a.png|120px]] |[[File:662_symmetry_0a0.png|120px]] |[[File:662_symmetry_z0z.png|120px]] |[[File:662_symmetry_xxx.png|120px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]] |[6,6]
{{CDD|node_c1|6|node_c3|6|node_c2}} |[1+,6,6]
{{CDD|node_h0|6|node_c3|6|node_c2}} = {{CDD||branch_c3|split2-66|node_c2}} |[6,6,1+]
{{CDD|node_c1|6|node_c3|6|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node_c1|split1-66|branch_c3|}} |[6,1+,6]
{{CDD|node_c1|6|node_h0|6|node_c2}} = {{CDD||branch_c1|2a2b-cross|branch_c2|}} |[1+,6,6,1+]
{{CDD|node_h0|6|node_c3|6|node_h0}} = {{CDD||branch_c3|3a3b-cross|branch_c3|}} |[6+,6+]
{{CDD|node_h2|6|node_h4|6|node_h2}} |- align=center !Orbifold |*662 |colspan=2|[[663 symmetry|*663]] |[[3232 symmetry|*3232]] |[[3333 symmetry|*3333]] |33× |- !colspan=7|Direct subgroups |- align=center !Diagram | |[[File:662_symmetry_0bb.png|120px]] |[[File:662_symmetry_bb0.png|120px]] |[[File:662_symmetry_b0b.png|120px]] |[[File:662_symmetry_0ab.png|120px]] |[[File:662_symmetry_ab0.png|120px]] |- align=center !Coxeter | |[6,6+]
{{CDD|node_c1|6|node_h2|6|node_h2}} |[6+,6]

= {{CDD|node_c1|6|node_h0|6|node_h2}} = {{CDD|branch_c1|2a2b-cross|branch_h2h2}} |[1+,6,1+,6]
{{CDD|node_h0|6|node_h0|6|node_c2}} = {{CDD|node_h0|6|node_h2|6|node_c2}} = {{CDD||branch_h2h2|split2-66|node_c2}}
= {{CDD|node_h2|6|node_h0|8|node_c2}} = {{CDD|branch_h2h2|2a2b-cross|branch_c2}} |- align=center !Orbifold | |colspan=2|6*3 |2*33 |colspan=2|3*33 |- !colspan=7|Direct subgroups |- align=center !Index !2 !colspan=3|4 !colspan=2|8 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:662_symmetry_aaa.png|120px]] |[[File:662_symmetry_abb.png|120px]] |[[File:662_symmetry_bba.png|120px]] |[[File:662_symmetry_bab.png|120px]] |colspan=2|[[File:662_symmetry_abc.png|120px]] |- align=center !Coxeter |[6,6]+
{{CDD|node_h2|6|node_h2|6|node_h2}} |[6,6+]+
{{CDD|node_h0|6|node_h2|6|node_h2}} = {{CDD||branch_h2h2|split2-66|node_h2}} |[6+,6]+

Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{isbn|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} ==See also== {{Commonscat|Uniform tiling 4-12-12}} *[[Square tiling]] *[[Tilings of regular polygons]] *[[List of uniform planar tilings]] *[[List of regular polytopes]] == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.plunk.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Hexagonal tilings]] [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Order-4 tilings]] [[Category:Truncated tilings]] [[Category:Uniform tilings]]

pages.title: Truncated order-4 octagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U84_01}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated order-4 octagonal tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of t0,1{8,4}. A secondary construction t0,1,2{8,8} is called a '''truncated octaoctagonal tiling''' with two colors of [[hexakaidecagon]]s. == Constructions == There are two uniform constructions of this tiling, first by the [8,4] [[kaleidoscope]], and second by removing the last mirror, [8,4,1+], gives [8,8], (*882). {| class=wikitable |+ Two uniform constructions of 4.8.4.8 |- align=center !Name !Tetraoctagonal !Truncated octaoctagonal |- align=center !Image |[[File:Uniform tiling 84-t01.png|100px]] |[[File:Uniform_tiling_88-t012.png|100px]] |- align=center ![[Hyperbolic symmetry|Symmetry]] |[8,4]
(*842)
{{CDD|node_c1|8|node_c2|4|node_c3}} |[8,8] = [8,4,1+]
(*882)
{{CDD|node_c1|split1-88|nodeab_c2}} = {{CDD|node_c1|8|node_c2|4|node_h0}} |- align=center !Symbol |t{8,4} |tr{8,8} |- align=center ![[Coxeter diagram]] |{{CDD|node_1|8|node_1|4|node}} |{{CDD|node_1|8|node_1|8|node_1}} |} == Dual tiling== {| class=wikitable width=320 |- |[[File:Order-8_tetrakis_square_tiling.png|160px]] |[[File:Hyperbolic domains 882.png|160px]] |- |colspan=2|The dual tiling, ''Order-8 tetrakis square tiling'' has [[face configuration]] V4.16.16, and represents the fundamental domains of the [8,8] symmetry group. |} == Symmetry== [[File:Truncated_order-4_octagonal_tiling_with_882_mirrors.png|thumb|left|Truncated order-4 octagonal tiling with *882 mirror lines]] The dual of the tiling represents the fundamental domains of (*882) [[Orbifold notation|orbifold]] symmetry. From [8,8] symmetry, there are 15 small index subgroup by mirror removal and [[Alternation (geometry)|alternation]] operators. Mirrors can be removed if its branch orders are all even, and cuts neighboring branch orders in half. Removing two mirrors leaves a half-order gyration point where the removed mirrors met. In these images unique mirrors are colored red, green, and blue, and alternatedly colored triangles show the location of gyration points. The [8+,8+], (44×) subgroup has narrow lines representing glide reflections. The [[subgroup index]]-8 group, [1+,8,1+,8,1+] (4444) is the [[commutator subgroup]] of [8,8]. One larger subgroup is constructed as [8,8*], removing the gyration points of (8*4), index 16 becomes (*44444444), and its direct subgroup [8,8*]+, index 32, (44444444). The [8,8] symmetry can be doubled by a mirror bisecting the fundamental domain, and creating [[884 symmetry|*884 symmetry]]. {| class=wikitable |+ Small index subgroups of [8,8] (*882) |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !colspan=3|2 !colspan=2|4 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:882_symmetry_000.png|120px]] |[[File:882_symmetry_a00.png|120px]] |[[File:882_symmetry_00a.png|120px]] |[[File:882_symmetry_0a0.png|120px]] |[[File:882_symmetry_a0b.png|120px]] |[[File:882_symmetry_xxx.png|120px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]] |[8,8]

{{CDD|node_c1|8|node_c3|8|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node_c1|split1-88|branch_c3|label4}} |[8,1+,8]
{{CDD|node_c1|8|node_h0|8|node_c2}} = {{CDD|label4|branch_c1|2a2b-cross|branch_c2|label4}} |[1+,8,8,1+]
{{CDD|node_h0|8|node_c3|8|node_h0}} = {{CDD|label4|branch_c3|4a4b-cross|branch_c3|label4}} |[8+,8+]
{{CDD|node_h2|8|node_h4|8|node_h2}} |- align=center ![[Orbifold notation|Orbifold]] |*882 |colspan=2|[[884 symmetry|*884]] |[[4242 symmetry|*4242]] |[[4444 symmetry|*4444]] |44× |- !colspan=7|Semidirect subgroups |- align=center !Diagram | |[[File:882_symmetry_0aa.png|120px]] |[[File:882_symmetry_aa0.png|120px]] |[[File:882_symmetry_a0a.png|120px]] |[[File:882_symmetry_0ab.png|120px]] |[[File:882_symmetry_ab0.png|120px]] |- align=center !Coxeter | |[8,8+]

pages.title: Truncated order-4 pentagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U54_01}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated order-4 pentagonal tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of t0,1{5,4}. == Uniform colorings == A half symmetry [1+,4,5] = [5,5] coloring can be constructed with two colors of decagons. This coloring is called a ''truncated pentapentagonal tiling''. :[[File:Uniform tiling 552-t012.png|240px]] == Symmetry == There is only one subgroup of [5,5], [5,5]+, removing all the mirrors. This symmetry can be doubled to [[542 symmetry]] by adding a bisecting mirror. {| class=wikitable |+ Small index subgroups of [5,5] |- align=center !Type !Reflective domains !Rotational symmetry |- align=center ![[subgroup index|Index]] !1 !2 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:552_symmetry_000.png|160px]] |[[File:552_symmetry_aaa.png|160px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]]
([[Orbifold notation|orbifold]]) |[5,5] = {{CDD|node_c1|5|node_c1|5|node_c1}} = {{CDD|node_c1|split1-55|branch_c1|label2}}
(*552) |[5,5]+ = {{CDD|node_h2|5|node_h2|5|node_h2}} = {{CDD|node_h2|split1-55|branch_h2h2|label2}}
(552) |} == Related polyhedra and tiling == {{Truncated_figure3_table}} {{Order 5-4 tiling table}} {{Order 5-5 tiling table}} ==References== * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{isbn|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} ==See also== {{Commonscat|Uniform tiling 4-10-10}} *[[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane]] *[[List of regular polytopes]] == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.plunk.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Order-4 tilings]] [[Category:Pentagonal tilings]] [[Category:Truncated tilings]] [[Category:Uniform tilings]] {{geometry-stub}}

pages.title: Truncated order-5 hexagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U65_01}}
In [[geometry]], the '''truncated order-5 hexagonal tiling''' is a [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform]] tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of t<sub>0,1</sub>{6,5}.

== Related polyhedra and tiling ==
{{Order 6-5 tiling table}}

==References==
* [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations)
* {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}}

==See also==

pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U66_01}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated order-6 hexagonal tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of t{6,6}. It can also be identically constructed as a '''cantic order-6 square tiling''', h2{4,6} == Uniform colorings == By *663 symmetry, this tiling can be constructed as an [[omnitruncation]], t{(6,6,3)}: :[[File:H2_tiling_366-7.png|240px]] == Symmetry == [[File:Truncated_order-6_hexagonal_tiling_with_mirrors.png|thumb|left|Truncated order-6 hexagonal tiling with *663 mirror lines]] The dual to this tiling represent the fundamental domains of [(6,6,3)] (*663) symmetry. There are 3 small index subgroup symmetries constructed from [(6,6,3)] by mirror removal and alternation. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and white, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. The symmetry can be doubled as [[662 symmetry]] by adding a mirror bisecting the fundamental domain. {{-}} {| class=wikitable |+ Small index subgroups of [(6,6,3)] (*663) |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !colspan=2|2 !6 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:663_symmetry_000.png|150px]] |[[File:663_symmetry_0a0.png|150px]] |[[File:663_symmetry_a0a.png|150px]] |[[File:663_symmetry_z0z.png|150px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]]
([[Orbifold notation|orbifold]]) |[(6,6,3)] = {{CDD|node_c1|split1-66|branch_c2}}
(*663) |[(6,1+,6,3)] = {{CDD|labelh|node|split1-66|branch_c2}} = {{CDD|branch_c2|3a3b-cross|branch_c2}}
([[3232 symmetry|*3333]]) |[(6,6,3+)] = {{CDD|node_c1|split1-66|branch_h2h2}}
(3*33) |[(6,6,3*)] = {{CDD|node_c1|split1-66|branch|labels}}
([[333333 symmetry|*333333]]) |- align=center !colspan=5|Direct subgroups |- align=center !Index !2 !colspan=2|4 !12 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:663_symmetry_aaa.png|150px]] |colspan=2|[[File:663_symmetry_abc.png|150px]] |[[File:663_symmetry_zaz.png|150px]] |- align=center !Coxeter
(orbifold) |[(6,6,3)]+ = {{CDD|node_h2|split1-66|branch_h2h2}}

Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{isbn|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} ==See also== *[[Square tiling]] *[[Tilings of regular polygons]] *[[List of uniform planar tilings]] *[[List of regular polytopes]] == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.plunk.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Hexagonal tilings]] [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Order-6 tilings]] [[Category:Truncated tilings]] [[Category:Uniform tilings]]

{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U86_01}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated order-6 octagonal tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of t{8,6}. == Uniform colorings == A secondary construction t{(8,8,3)} is called a '''truncated trioctaoctagonal tiling''': :[[File:H2 tiling 388-7.png|240px]] == Symmetry == [[File:Truncated_order-6_octagonal_tiling_with_mirrors.png|left|thumb|Truncated order-6 octagonal tiling with mirror lines, {{CDD|node_c1|split1-88|branch_c2}}]] The dual to this tiling represent the fundamental domains of [(8,8,3)] (*883) symmetry. There are 3 small index subgroup symmetries constructed from [(8,8,3)] by mirror removal and alternation. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and white, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. The symmetry can be doubled as [[862 symmetry]] by adding a mirror bisecting the fundamental domain. {{-}} {| class=wikitable |+ Small index subgroups of [(8,8,3)] (*883) |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !colspan=2|2 !6 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:883_symmetry_000.png|150px]] |[[File:883_symmetry_0a0.png|150px]] |[[File:883_symmetry_a0a.png|150px]] |[[File:883_symmetry_z0z.png|150px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]]

{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U65_12}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated order-6 pentagonal tiling''' is a [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform]] tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of t1,2{6,5}. == Uniform colorings == {| class=wikitable width=480 |- align=center |[[File:H2_tiling_355-7.png|240px]]
t012(5,5,3) |[[File:H2_tiling_355-7-mirrors.png|240px]]
With mirrors |- |colspan=2|An alternate construction exists from the [(5,5,3)] family, as the omnitruncation t012(5,5,3). It is shown with two (colors) of [[decagon]]s. |} == Symmetry == The dual of this tiling represents the fundamental domains of the *553 symmetry. There are no mirror removal subgroups of [(5,5,3)], but this symmetry group can be doubled to [[652 symmetry]] by adding a bisecting mirror to the fundamental domains. {| class=wikitable |+ Small index subgroups of [(5,5,3)] |- align=center !Type !Reflective domains !Rotational symmetry |- align=center ![[subgroup index|Index]] !1 !2 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:553_symmetry_000.png|160px]] |[[File:553_symmetry_aaa.png|160px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]]

(553) |} == Related polyhedra and tiling == {{Order 6-5 tiling table}} {| class=wikitable |+ [(5,5,3)] reflective symmetry uniform tilings |- |[[File:H2 tiling 355-1.png|60px]] |[[File:H2 tiling 355-2.png|60px]] |[[File:H2 tiling 355-3.png|60px]] |[[File:H2 tiling 355-4.png|60px]] |[[File:H2 tiling 355-5.png|60px]] |[[File:H2 tiling 355-6.png|60px]] |[[File:H2 tiling 355-7.png|60px]] |} ==References== * [[John Horton Conway|John H. pages.title: Truncated order-6 square tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U64_12}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated order-6 square tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of t{4,6}. == Uniform colorings == {| class=wikitable width=240 |- valign=top |[[File:Uniform_tiling_443-t012.png|240px]]
The half symmetry [1+,6,4] = [(4,4,3)] can be shown with alternating two colors of octagons, with as [[Coxeter diagram]] {{CDD|branch_11|split2-44|node_1}}. |} == Symmetry == [[File:Truncated_order-6_square_tiling_with_mirrors.png|thumb|left|Truncated order-6 square tiling with *443 symmetry mirror lines]] The dual tiling represents the fundamental domains of the *443 orbifold symmetry. There are two reflective subgroup kaleidoscopic constructed from [(4,4,3)] by removing one or two of three mirrors. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and cyan, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. A larger subgroup is constructed [(4,4,3*)], index 6, as (3*22) with gyration points removed, becomes (*222222). The symmetry can be doubled as [[642 symmetry]] by adding a mirror bisecting the fundamental domain. {{-}} {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" !colspan=12| Small index subgroups of [(4,4,3)] (*443) |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !colspan=2|2 !6 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:443_symmetry_000.png|150px]] |[[File:443_symmetry_0a0.png|150px]] |[[File:443_symmetry_a0a.png|150px]] |[[File:443_symmetry_z0z.png|150px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]]
([[Orbifold notation|orbifold]]) |[(4,4,3)] = {{CDD|node_c1|split1-44|branch_c2}}
(*443) |[(4,1+,4,3)] = {{CDD|labelh|node|split1-44|branch_c2}} = {{CDD|branch_c2|2a2b-cross|branch_c2}}
([[3232 symmetry|*3232]]) |[(4,4,3+)] = {{CDD|node_c1|split1-44|branch_h2h2}}
(3*22) |[(4,4,3*)] = {{CDD|node_c1|split1-44|branch|labels}}
([[222222 symmetry|*222222]]) |- !colspan=5|Direct subgroups |- align=center !Index !2 !colspan=2|4 !12 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:443_symmetry_aaa.png|150px]] |colspan=2|[[File:443_symmetry_abc.png|150px]] |[[File:443_symmetry_zaz.png|150px]] |- align=center !Coxeter
(orbifold) |[(4,4,3)]+ = {{CDD|node_h2|split1-44|branch_h2h2}}
(443) |colspan=2|[(4,4,3+)]+ = {{CDD|labelh|node|split1-44|branch_h2h2}} = {{CDD|branch_h2h2|2xa2xb-cross|branch_h2h2}}
(3232) |[(4,4,3*)]+ = {{CDD|node_h2|split1-44|branch|labels}}
(222222) |} == Related polyhedra and tiling == From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are eight hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular order-4 hexagonal tiling. Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 8 forms. {{Order 6-4 tiling table}} It can also be generated from the (4 4 3) hyperbolic tilings: {{Order 4-4-3 tiling table}} {{Truncated figure4 table}} ==See also== {{Commonscat|Uniform tiling 6-8-8}} *[[Square tiling]] *[[Tilings of regular polygons]] *[[List of uniform planar tilings]] *[[List of regular polytopes]] ==References== * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{isbn|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.plunk.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Order-6 tilings]] [[Category:Square tilings]] [[Category:Truncated tilings]] [[Category:Uniform tilings]]

pages.title: Truncated order-7 heptagonal tiling
Truncated order-7 square tiling
Truncated order-7 triangular tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U73_12}} In [[geometry]], the '''Order-7 truncated triangular tiling''', sometimes called the '''hyperbolic soccerball''',[http://www.theiff.org/images/IFF_HypSoccerBall.pdf HOW TO BUILD YOUR OWN HYPERBOLIC SOCCER BALL MODEL] is a semiregular tiling of the hyperbolic plane. There are two [[hexagon]]s and one [[heptagon]] on each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]], forming a pattern similar to a conventional [[Association football ball|soccer ball]] ([[truncated icosahedron]]) with heptagons in place of [[pentagon]]s. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of t{3,7}. == Hyperbolic soccerball (football) == This tiling is called a '''hyperbolic soccerball''' (football) for its similarity to the [[truncated icosahedron]] pattern used on [[Association football|soccer]] balls. Small portions of it as a hyperbolic surface can be constructed in 3-space. {| class=wikitable width=455 |- valign=top |[[File:Comparison of truncated icosahedron and soccer ball.png|200px]]
A [[truncated icosahedron]]
as a [[polyhedron]] and a [[ball]] |[[File:Uniform tiling 63-t12.png|120px]]
The Euclidean [[Hexagonal tiling#Uniform colorings|hexagonal tiling]]
colored as truncated
[[triangular tiling]] |[[Image:Hyperbolicsoccerball.jpg|160px]]
A paper construction
of a hyperbolic soccerball |} == Dual tiling == The dual tiling is called a ''heptakis heptagonal tiling'', named for being constructible as a [[heptagonal tiling]] with every heptagon divided into seven triangles by the center point. :[[Image:Order3 heptakis heptagonal til.png|250px]] == Related tilings == This hyperbolic tiling is topologically related as a part of sequence of uniform [[Truncation (geometry)|truncated]] polyhedra with [[vertex configuration]]s (n.6.6), and [n,3] [[Coxeter group]] symmetry. {{Truncated figure2 table}} From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are eight hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular heptagonal tiling. Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 8 forms. {{Heptagonal tiling table}} == See also == {{Commonscat|Uniform tiling 6-6-7}} * [[Triangular tiling]] * [[Order-3 heptagonal tiling]] * [[Order-7 triangular tiling]] * [[Tilings of regular polygons]] * [[List of uniform tilings]] ==References== * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.hadron.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] * [http://www.math.tamu.edu/~sottile/research/stories/hyperbolic_football/index.html Geometric explorations on the hyperbolic football by Frank Sottile] {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Order-7 tilings]] [[Category:Semiregular tilings]] [[Category:Triangular tilings]] [[Category:Truncated tilings]]

pages.title: Truncated order-8 hexagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U86_12}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated order-8 hexagonal tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the hyperbolic plane. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of t{6,8}. == Uniform colorings == This tiling can also be constructed from *664 symmetry, as t{(6,6,4)}. :[[File:H2_tiling_466-7.png|240px]] == Related polyhedra and tilings == From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are fourteen hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular order-6 octagonal tiling. Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 7 forms with full [8,6] symmetry, and 7 with subsymmetry. {{Order 8-6 tiling table}} === Symmetry === The dual of the tiling represents the fundamental domains of (*664) [[Orbifold notation|orbifold]] symmetry. From [(6,6,4)] (*664) symmetry, there are 15 small index subgroup (11 unique) by mirror removal and alternation operators. Mirrors can be removed if its branch orders are all even, and cuts neighboring branch orders in half. Removing two mirrors leaves a half-order gyration point where the removed mirrors met. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and white, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. The symmetry can be doubled to [[862 symmetry]] by adding a bisecting mirror across the fundamental domains. The [[subgroup index]]-8 group, [(1+,6,1+,6,1+,4)] (332332) is the [[commutator subgroup]] of [(6,6,4)]. A large subgroup is constructed [(6,6,4*)], index 8, as (4*33) with gyration points removed, becomes (*38), and another large subgroup is constructed [(6,6*,4)], index 12, as (6*32) with gyration points removed, becomes (*(32)6). {| class=wikitable |+ Small index subgroups of [(6,6,4)] (*664) |- align=center !Fundamental
domains ![[File:H2checkers 466.png|120px]] ![[File:H2chess 466e.png|80px]]

pages.title: Truncated order-8 octagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U88_01}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated order-8 octagonal tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of t0,1{8,8}. == Uniform colorings == This tiling can also be constructed in *884 symmetry with 3 colors of faces: :[[File:H2_tiling_488-7.png|240px]] == Related polyhedra and tiling == {{Order 8-8 tiling table}} === Symmetry === The dual of the tiling represents the fundamental domains of (*884) [[Orbifold notation|orbifold]] symmetry. From [(8,8,4)] (*884) symmetry, there are 15 small index subgroup (11 unique) by mirror removal and alternation operators. Mirrors can be removed if its branch orders are all even, and cuts neighboring branch orders in half. Removing two mirrors leaves a half-order gyration point where the removed mirrors met. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and white, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. The symmetry can be doubled to [[882 symmetry]] by adding a bisecting mirror across the fundamental domains. The [[subgroup index]]-8 group, [(1+,8,1+,8,1+,4)] (442442) is the [[commutator subgroup]] of [(8,8,4)]. {| class=wikitable |+ Small index subgroups of [(8,8,4)] (*884) |- align=center !Fundamental

pages.title: Truncated order-8 triangular tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U83_12}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated order-8 triangular tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the hyperbolic plane. There are two [[hexagon]]s and one [[octagon]] on each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of t{3,8}. == Uniform colors== {| class=wikitable width=480 |- valign=top align=center |[[File:H2 tiling 334-7.png|240px]]
The half symmetry [1+,8,3] = [(4,3,3)] can be shown with alternating two colors of hexagons |[[File:Uniform dual tiling 433-t012.png|240px]]
Dual tiling |} == Symmetry == The dual of this tiling represents the fundamental domains of *443 symmetry. It only has one subgroup 443, replacing mirrors with gyration points. This symmetry can be doubled to [[832 symmetry]] by adding a bisecting mirror to the fundamental domain. {| class=wikitable |+ Small index subgroups of [(4,3,3)], (*433) |- align=center !Type !Reflectional !Rotational |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !2 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:433_symmetry_000.png|160px]] |[[File:433_symmetry_aaa.png|160px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]]
([[Orbifold notation|orbifold]]) |[(4,3,3)] = {{CDD|node_c1|split1|branch_c1|label4}}
(*433) |[(4,3,3)]+ = {{CDD|node_h2|split1|branch_h2h2|label4}}
(433) |} == Related tilings == From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are ten hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular octagonal tiling. {{Octagonal tiling table}} It can also be generated from the (4 3 3) hyperbolic tilings: {{Order 4-3-3 tiling table}} This hyperbolic tiling is topologically related as a part of sequence of uniform [[Truncation (geometry)|truncated]] polyhedra with [[vertex configuration]]s (n.6.6), and [n,3] [[Coxeter group]] symmetry. {{Truncated figure2 table}} == See also == {{Commonscat|Uniform tiling 6-6-8}} * [[Triangular tiling]] * [[Order-3 octagonal tiling]] * [[Order-8 triangular tiling]] * [[Tilings of regular polygons]] * [[List of uniform tilings]] ==References== * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{isbn|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.hadron.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Order-8 tilings]] [[Category:Semiregular tilings]] [[Category:Triangular tilings]] [[Category:Truncated tilings]] {{geometry-stub}}

pages.title: Truncated pentahexagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U65_012}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated tetrahexagonal tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the hyperbolic plane. There are one [[Square (geometry)|square]], one [[decagon]], and one [[dodecagon]] on each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of ''t0,1,2{6,5}''. Its name is somewhat misleading: literal geometric truncation of [[pentahexagonal tiling]] produces rectangles instead of squares. == Dual tiling== {| class="wikitable" width="320" |[[File:H2checkers_256.png|160px]] |[[File:Hyperbolic domains 652.png|160px]] |- | colspan="2" |The dual tiling is called an ''order-5-6 kisrhombille tiling'', made as a complete bisection of the [[order-5 hexagonal tiling]], here with triangles shown in alternating colors. This tiling represents the fundamental triangular domains of [6,5] (*652) symmetry. |} == Symmetry== There are four small index subgroup from [6,5] by mirror removal and alternation. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and white, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. {| class=wikitable |+ Small index subgroups of [6,5], (*652) |- align=center |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !colspan=2|2 !6 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:652_symmetry_000.png|120px]] |[[File:652_symmetry_a00.png|120px]] |[[File:652_symmetry_0bb.png|120px]] |[[File:652_symmetry_0zz.png|120px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]]
([[Orbifold notation|orbifold]]) |[6,5] = {{CDD|node_c1|6|node_c2|5|node_c2}}
(*652) |[1+,6,5] = {{CDD|node_h0|6|node_c2|5|node_c2}} = {{CDD|branch_c2|split2-55|node_c2}}
([[553 symmetry|*553]]) |[6,5+] = {{CDD|node_c1|6|node_h2|5|node_h2}}
(5*3) |[6,5*] = {{CDD|node_c1|6|node_g|5|3sg|node_g}}
([[33333 symmetry|*33333]]) |- align=center !colspan=5|Direct subgroups |- align=center !Index !2 !colspan=2|4 !12 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:652_symmetry_aaa.png|120px]] |colspan=2|[[File:652_symmetry_abb.png|120px]] |[[File:652_symmetry_azz.png|120px]] |- align=center !Coxeter
(orbifold) |[6,5]+ = {{CDD|node_h2|6|node_h2|5|node_h2}}
(652) |colspan=2|[6,5+]+ = {{CDD|node_h0|6|node_h2|5|node_h2}} = {{CDD|branch_h2h2|split2-55|node_h2}}
(553) |[6,5*]+ = {{CDD|node_h2|6|node_g|3sg|node_g}}
(33333) |} == Related polyhedra and tilings == From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are fourteen hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular order-5 hexagonal tiling. Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 7 forms with full [6,5] symmetry, and 3 with subsymmetry. {{Order 6-5 tiling table}} == See also == * [[Tilings of regular polygons]] * [[List of uniform planar tilings]] ==References== * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{isbn|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.hadron.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Semiregular tilings]] [[Category:Truncated tilings]]

pages.title: Truncated tetraapeirogonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|Ui4_012}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated tetraapeirogonal tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the hyperbolic plane. There are one [[Square (geometry)|square]], one [[octagon]], and one [[apeirogon]] on each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of tr{∞,4}. == Related polyhedra and tilings == {{Order i-4 tiling table}} {{Omnitruncated4 table}} {{Omnitruncated_symmetric_table}} == Symmetry== The dual of this tiling represents the fundamental domains of [∞,4], (*∞42) symmetry. There are 15 small index subgroups constructed from [∞,4] by mirror removal and alternation. Mirrors can be removed if its branch orders are all even, and cuts neighboring branch orders in half. Removing two mirrors leaves a half-order gyration point where the removed mirrors met. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and white, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. The [[subgroup index]]-8 group, [1+,∞,1+,4,1+] (∞2∞2) is the [[commutator subgroup]] of [∞,4]. A larger subgroup is constructed as [∞,4*], index 8, as [∞,4+], (4*∞) with gyration points removed, becomes (*∞∞∞∞) or (*∞4), and another [∞*,4], index ∞ as [∞+,4], (∞*2) with gyration points removed as (*2∞). And their direct subgroups [∞,4*]+, [∞*,4]+, subgroup indices 16 and ∞ respectively, can be given in orbifold notation as (∞∞∞∞) and (2∞). {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" !colspan=12| Small index subgroups of [∞,4], (*∞42) |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !colspan=3|2 !colspan=2|4 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:i42 symmetry 000.png|120px]] |[[File:i42 symmetry a00.png|120px]] |[[File:i42 symmetry 00a.png|120px]] |[[File:i42 symmetry 0a0.png|120px]] |[[File:i42 symmetry z0z.png|120px]] |[[File:i42 symmetry xxx.png|120px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]] |[∞,4]

pages.title: Truncated tetraheptagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U74_012}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated tetraheptagonal tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of tr{4,7}. ==Images== Poincaré disk projection, centered on 14-gon: :[[File:Uniform tiling 74-t012.png|160px]] == Symmetry== [[File:Truncated_tetraheptagonal_tiling_with_mirrors.png|thumb|left|Truncated tetraheptagonal tiling with mirror lines. {{CDD|node_c1|7|node_c1|4|node_c2}}]] The dual to this tiling represents the fundamental domains of [7,4] (*742) symmetry. There are 3 small index subgroups constructed from [7,4] by mirror removal and alternation. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and white, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. {{-}} {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" !colspan=12| Small index subgroups of [7,4] (*742) |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !colspan=2|2 !14 |- align=center !Diagram ![[File:742_symmetry_000.png|160px]] ![[File:742_symmetry_00a.png|160px]] ![[File:742_symmetry_bb0.png|160px]] ![[File:742_symmetry_zz0.png|160px]] |- ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]]
([[Orbifold notation|orbifold]]) ![7,4] = {{CDD|node_c1|7|node_c1|4|node_c2}}
(*742) ![7,4,1+] = {{CDD|node_c1|7|node_c1|4|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node_c1|split1-77|nodeab_c1}}
([[772 symmetry|*772]]) ![7+,4] = {{CDD|node_h2|7|node_h2|4|node_c2}}

pages.title: Truncated tetrahexagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U64_012}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated tetrahexagonal tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the hyperbolic plane. There are one [[Square (geometry)|square]], one [[octagon]], and one [[dodecagon]] on each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of tr{6,4}. == Dual tiling== {| class=wikitable width=320 |[[File:H2checkers_246.png|160px]] |[[File:Hyperbolic domains 642.png|160px]] |- |colspan=2|The dual tiling is called an ''order-4-6 kisrhombille tiling'', made as a complete bisection of the [[order-4 hexagonal tiling]], here with triangles shown in alternating colors. This tiling represents the fundamental triangular domains of [6,4] (*642) symmetry. |} {{-}} == Related polyhedra and tilings == {{Omnitruncated4 table}} {{Omnitruncated_symmetric_table}} From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are fourteen hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular order-4 hexagonal tiling. Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 7 forms with full [6,4] symmetry, and 7 with subsymmetry. {{Order 6-4 tiling table}} == Symmetry== [[File:Truncated_tetrahexagonal_tiling_with_mirrors.png|thumb|left|Truncated tetrahexagonal tiling with mirror lines in green, red, and blue: {{CDD|node_c3|6|node_c1|4|node_c2}}]] [[File:Tetrahexagonal tiling subgroups.png|thumb|Symmetry diagrams for small index subgroups of [6,4], shown in a hexagonal translational cell within a [[Order-6 hexagonal tiling|{6,6} tiling]], with a fundamental domain in yellow.]] The dual of the tiling represents the fundamental domains of (*642) [[Orbifold notation|orbifold]] symmetry. From [6,4] symmetry, there are 15 small index subgroup by mirror removal and [[Alternation (geometry)|alternation]] operators. Mirrors can be removed if its branch orders are all even, and cuts neighboring branch orders in half. Removing two mirrors leaves a half-order gyration point where the removed mirrors met. In these images unique mirrors are colored red, green, and blue, and alternatedly colored triangles show the location of gyration points. The [6+,4+], (32×) subgroup has narrow lines representing glide reflections. The [[subgroup index]]-8 group, [1+,6,1+,4,1+] (3232) is the [[commutator subgroup]] of [6,4]. Larger subgroup constructed as [6,4*], removing the gyration points of [6,4+], (3*22), index 6 becomes ([[3333 symmetry|*3333]]), and [6*,4], removing the gyration points of [6+,4], (2*33), index 12 as ([[222222 symmetry|*222222]]). Finally their direct subgroups [6,4*]+, [6*,4]+, subgroup indices 12 and 24 respectively, can be given in orbifold notation as (3333) and (222222). {{-}} {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" !colspan=12| Small index subgroups of [6,4] |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !colspan=3|2 !colspan=4|4 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:642 symmetry 000.png|100px]] |[[File:642 symmetry a00.png|100px]] |[[File:642 symmetry 00a.png|100px]] |[[File:642 symmetry 0a0.png|100px]] |[[File:642 symmetry a0b.png|100px]] |[[File:642 symmetry xxx.png|100px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]] |[6,4]

pages.title: Truncated tetraoctagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U84_012}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated tetraoctagonal tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the hyperbolic plane. There are one [[Square (geometry)|square]], one [[octagon]], and one [[hexakaidecagon]] on each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of tr{8,4}. == Dual tiling== {| class=wikitable width=320 |[[File:H2checkers 248.png|160px]] |[[File:Hyperbolic domains 842.png|160px]] |- |colspan=2|The dual tiling is called an ''order-4-8 kisrhombille tiling'', made as a complete bisection of the [[order-4 octagonal tiling]], here with triangles are shown with alternating colors. This tiling represents the fundamental triangular domains of [8,4] (*842) symmetry. |} === Symmetry=== [[File:Truncated_tetraoctagonal_tiling_with_mirrors.png|thumb|left|Truncated tetraoctagonal tiling with *842, {{CDD|node_c2|8|node_c3|4|node_c1}}, mirror lines]] There are 15 subgroups constructed from [8,4] by mirror removal and alternation. Mirrors can be removed if its branch orders are all even, and cuts neighboring branch orders in half. Removing two mirrors leaves a half-order gyration point where the removed mirrors met. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and white, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. The [[subgroup index]]-8 group, [1+,8,1+,4,1+] (4242) is the [[commutator subgroup]] of [8,4]. A larger subgroup is constructed as [8,4*], index 8, as [8,4+], (4*4) with gyration points removed, becomes (*4444) or (*44), and another [8*,4], index 16 as [8+,4], (8*2) with gyration points removed as (*22222222) or (*28). And their direct subgroups [8,4*]+, [8*,4]+, subgroup indices 16 and 32 respectively, can be given in orbifold notation as (4444) and (22222222). {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" !colspan=12| Small index subgroups of [8,4] (*842) |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !colspan=3|2 !colspan=2|4 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:842 symmetry mirrors.png|120px]] |[[File:842 symmetry 00a.png|120px]] |[[File:842 symmetry a00.png|120px]] |[[File:842 symmetry 0a0.png|120px]] |[[File:842 symmetry a0b.png|120px]] |[[File:842 symmetry xxx.png|120px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]] |[8,4]

pages.title: Truncated tetrapentagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U54_012}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated tetrapentagonal tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of t0,1,2{4,5} or tr{4,5}. == Symmetry== [[File:Truncated_tetrapentagonal_tiling_with_mirrors.png|thumb|left|Truncated tetrapentagonal tiling with mirror lines. {{CDD|node_c1|5|node_c1|4|node_c2}}]] There are four small index subgroup constructed from [5,4] by mirror removal and alternation. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and white, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. {{-}} A radical subgroup is constructed [5*,4], index 10, as [5+,4], (5*2) with gyration points removed, becoming orbifold ([[22222 symmetry|*22222]]), and its direct subgroup [5*,4]+, index 20, becomes orbifold (22222). {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" !colspan=12| Small index subgroups of [5,4] |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !colspan=2|2 !10 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:542 symmetry 000.png|160px]] |[[File:542 symmetry 00a.png|160px]] |[[File:542 symmetry bb0.png|160px]] |[[File:542 symmetry zz0.png|160px]] |- ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]]

pages.title: Truncated triapeirogonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|Ui3_012}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated triapeirogonal tiling''' is a [[uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tiling]] of the [[hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]] with a [[Schläfli symbol]] of tr{∞,3}. == Symmetry== [[File:Truncated_triapeirogonal_tiling_with_mirrors.png|thumb|left|Truncated triapeirogonal tiling with mirrors]] The dual of this tiling represents the fundamental domains of [∞,3], *∞32 symmetry. There are 3 small index subgroup constructed from [∞,3] by mirror removal and alternation. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and white, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. A special index 4 reflective subgroup, is [(∞,∞,3)], (*∞∞3), and its direct subgroup [(∞,∞,3)]+, (∞∞3), and semidirect subgroup [(∞,∞,3+)], (3*∞).Norman W. Johnson and Asia Ivic Weiss, ''Quadratic Integers and Coxeter Groups'', Can. J. Math. Vol. 51 (6), 1999 pp. 1307–1336 [http://cms.math.ca/cjm/v51/weisscox8.pdf] Given [∞,3] with generating mirrors {0,1,2}, then its index 4 subgroup has generators {0,121,212}. An index 6 subgroup constructed as [∞,3*], becomes [(∞,∞,∞)], (*∞∞∞). {| class=wikitable |+ Small index subgroups of [∞,3], (*∞32) |- align=center |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !colspan=2|2 !3 !4 !colspan=2|6 !8 !12 !24 |- align=center !Diagrams |[[File:i32 symmetry mirrors.png|80px]] |[[File:i32_symmetry_a00.png|80px]] |[[File:i32_symmetry_0bb.png|80px]] |[[File:I32_symmetry_mirrors-index3.png|80px]] |[[File:I32_symmetry_mirrors-index4a.png|80px]] |[[File:i32_symmetry_0zz.png|80px]] |[[File:I32_symmetry_mirrors-index6-i2i2.png|80px]] |[[File:I32_symmetry_mirrors-index8a.png|80px]] |[[File:I32_symmetry_mirrors-index12a.png|80px]] |[[File:I32_symmetry_mirrors-index24a.png|80px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]]
([[Orbifold notation|orbifold]]) |[∞,3]

(∞6) |} == Related polyhedra and tiling == {{Order i-3 tiling table}} This tiling can be considered a member of a sequence of uniform patterns with vertex figure (4.6.2p) and [[Coxeter-Dynkin diagram]] {{CDD|node_1|p|node_1|3|node_1}}. For ''p'' < 6, the members of the sequence are [[Omnitruncation (geometry)|omnitruncated]] polyhedra ([[zonohedron]]s), shown below as spherical tilings. For ''p'' > 6, they are tilings of the hyperbolic plane, starting with the [[truncated triheptagonal tiling]]. {{Omnitruncated table}} ==See also== {{Commons category|Uniform tiling 4-6-i}} *[[List of uniform planar tilings]] *[[Tilings of regular polygons]] *[[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{refbegin}} * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Apeirogonal tilings]] [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Truncated tilings]] [[Category:Uniform tilings]]

pages.title: Truncated triheptagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U73_012}}
In [[geometry]], the '''truncated triheptagonal tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the hyperbolic plane. There are one [[Square (geometry)|square]], one [[hexagon]], and one [[tetradecagon]] (14-sides) on each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]].  It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of ''tr''{7,3}.

== Uniform colorings ==
There is only one [[uniform coloring]] of a truncated triheptagonal tiling. (Naming the colors by indices around a vertex: 123.)

== Symmetry ==
Each [[Order 3-7 kisrhombille#Symmetry|triangle in this dual tiling, order 3-7 kisrhombille]], represent a fundamental domain of the [[Wythoff construction]] for the symmetry group [7,3].

{| class=wikitable width=480
|[[File:Truncated_triheptagonal_tiling_with_mirrors.png|240px]]
|[[File:H2checkers_237.png|240px]]
|-
|colspan=3|The dual tiling is called an ''order-3 bisected heptagonal tiling'', made as a complete bisection of the [[heptagonal tiling]], here shown with triangles with alternating colors. 
|}

== Related polyhedra and tilings ==
This tiling can be considered a member of a sequence of uniform patterns with vertex figure (4.6.2p) and [[Coxeter-Dynkin diagram]] {{CDD|node_1|p|node_1|3|node_1}}.  For ''p'' < 6, the members of the sequence are [[Omnitruncation (geometry)|omnitruncated]] polyhedra ([[zonohedron]]s), shown below as spherical tilings. For ''p'' > 6, they are tilings of the hyperbolic plane, starting with the truncated triheptagonal tiling.
{{Omnitruncated table}}

From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are eight hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular heptagonal tiling.

Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 8 forms.

{{Heptagonal tiling table}}

== See also ==
{{Commons category|Uniform tiling 4-6-14}}
* [[Tilings of regular polygons]]
* [[List of uniform planar tilings]]

==References==
* [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{isbn|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations)
* {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}}
